newsitem.title: FRANCE: Labour minister Aubry is Socialists' rising star.
newsitem.headline: Labour minister Aubry is Socialists' rising star.

text.p: Martine Aubry, France's new superminister for employment and social solidarity, is a key strategist for Prime Minister Lionel Jospin and one of his Socialist party's most popular rising stars.
At 46, Aubry, a courteous but earnest technocrat in the mould of her father, former European Commission president Jacques Delors, becomes number two in the Jospin government.

Her sharp mind and dynamic, hands-on style won her a leading role among the "quadras", or fortysomethings, who have revived the battered, sleaze-tainted party since it was ousted from power in a 1993 conservative landslide.
During the campaign for last Sunday's parliamentary election, she was a fixture on television, debating rival political heavyweights in a dry but forceful manner.

Like her father, she consistently ranks among the nation's five most popular politicians and is often mentioned as a possible future Socialist prime minister or even as the nation's first woman president.
A former labour minister in two cabinets in 1991-93, she has cast herself as a champion of the millions left unemployed and without hope by the last decade's economic upheavals.

After the Socialists lost power, Aubry kept herself in the public eye with her own anti-unemployment foundation, Agir contre l'Exclusion (Action against Poverty), funded by leading industrialists with whom she is on excellent terms.

"We must give hope to those young people who are suffering and have lost their faith," she said in a recent interview. "In any case, what we have been able to accomplish is only a few drops of water in an ocean of exclusion."

She has also methodically built a power base in the northern city of Lille, serving as deputy to mayor Pierre Mauroy, a former prime minister, and winning a parliamentary seat for a Lille constituency in the general election.
When her father decided against running for the presidency in 1995, Aubry was even cited, at the relatively young age of 44, as a potential candidate.

She argued that the centre-right government's austerity programme, put in place to help France qualify for a single European currency, should not be used as an excuse to ignore record 12.8 percent unemployment.
"The short-term problem in France is to boost consumer demand, and thus encourage our businesses to invest," she said in a recent television appearance.
While her father is a symbol of European integration, Aubry toes the Socialist Party's current line favouring a more cautious and conditional approach to European monetary union.

Aubry first stepped into the spotlight when Edith Cresson, France's first woman prime minister, plucked her from the obscurity of state-owned aluminium firm Pechiney to make her labour minister in 1991.

Her tenure was characterised by a gritty commitment to her work and a refusal to be discouraged by mounting job losses which took unemployment over three million. Her schemes were marked by a common element -- they were inexpensive.
Her grass roots approach was typified by surprise visits to neighbourhood job centres to chat to staff and the unemployed.
Born Martine Delors on August 8, 1950, in Paris, she married accountant Xavier Aubry in October 1973. They have a daughter. Her hobbies are tennis and skiing.
